note.body:
Your fix breaks API and ABI. You're not allowed to remove a method, however
wrong it is. The removal must wait until gtkmm5, probably many years ahead.
I've fixed the bug by adding Gtk::Snapshot::render_background() without
removing anything.

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body: `cppgir` handles it much more elegant. It also supports `Gtk::BuilderCScope`. However, it doesn't support `Gtk::Snapshot`, so there is no chance to subclass `Gtk::Widget`. Nothing's ever easy. 😁

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body: Ah, I never got around using that hack myself; I register my objects by calling their constructors [in my application's `on_activate` handler](https://github.com/JacksonCampolattaro/widgets/blob/cabd9e5e73a0a3507c97b7e7b29657b31cfff28c/demo/main.cpp#L44-L48) (the void-cast is just to avoid unused variable warnings).

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body: Yeah... that code from StackOverflow uses a hack: it creates a temporary object of the derived class in the `Gtk::Application::startup` handler. This temporary object registers the type; only after that can `Gtk::Builder` create `gtkmmm_CustomObject_...`. I think it will do but it is nasty. A solution via `BuilderScope` would have been more elegant. Thank you for giving me access to your repository, I will take a look.

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body:
Ah sorry, forgot that repo was private; the links should work now! I think my use case might be the reverse of yours: I wanted to define a [widget template](https://developer.gnome.org/documentation/tutorials/widget-templates.html)'s structure in a `.blp` file and then be able to instantiate it as a C++ widget.

If I understand correctly, you want to define a widget in pure C++ and then use it in your blueprints; sort of like [like this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72157547/gtkmm-how-do-i-use-a-custom-widget-in-a-gtkbuilder-xml-file), but in a `.blp` file instead of XML? That might not actually require any extra hacks; once I got my template widget working I could place it in my blueprints as long as I used the `gtkmmm_CustomObject_` prefix.

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body: Thank you, Jackson. Your link shows error 404. Forgive me for my ignorance; what does it do with GTK templates? I am not well familiar with this concept. I am trying to subclass GtkWidget, similar to `path_text.c` from GTK4 Demo, and reference my widget in a .blp file.

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body: Hey, I ended up implementing my approach [here](https://github.com/JacksonCampolattaro/widgets)! I call the `gtk_builder_extend_with_template` (C) function directly in my [`TemplateWidget`](https://github.com/JacksonCampolattaro/widgets/blob/main/demo/TemplateWidget.h) helper class, and then all my resources have the `gtkmmm_CustomObject_` prefix. [`demo.blp`](https://github.com/JacksonCampolattaro/widgets/blob/main/resources/demo.blp) has an example of one widget that includes another; I think the same approach would work for XML definitions.

target_title: Gtk BuilderScope vfuncs not wrapped in gtkmm

note.body:
From a [comment by Emmanuele Bassi](https://discourse.gnome.org/t/shall-applications-call-virtual-function-gtkwidgetclass-snapshot/24545/4) on Discourse:

> What the author of the issue is doing is quite broken: you’re **never** supposed to call the virtual function of a widget directly. The only time you’re supposed to do that is when subclassing a widget and chaining up.

> You should not be calling the `snapshot()` virtual function on an unsuspecting `GtkWidget`.

A non-virtual Gtk::Widget::snapshot() function will not be added in gtkmm, unless
a corresponding non-virtual public function is added in gtk. The virtual functions
will continue to be protected in gtkmm.

If you don't like the Paintable that Gtk::WidgetPaintable::create() creates,
I suggest that you file a gtk issue, explaining what you want.

The culprit is this function in glibmm/glib/glibmm/ustring.h:
```
template <typename T, typename = std::enable_if_t<!std::is_base_of_v<ustring, T>>>
inline bool
operator==(const ustring& lhs, const T& rhs)
{
  return (lhs.compare(rhs) == 0);
}
```
It accepts too many types, `T`, also types that can't be compared to a Glib::ustring.
Overload resolution considers only function declarations. It ignores function definitions.

I'll move this issue to glibmm.

This was also true of `Widget::draw()` in GTK3. I guess the question is: should vfuncs be protected? (All, or some?)

Note the `WidgetPaintable` alternative has some slightly different properties, like maintaining a "live" preview of the widget, which might not be desirable for e.g. a screenshot tool.

If you don't need the Snapshot, just the Paintable, this is an alternative:
```
return Gtk::WidgetPaintable::create(*my_widget);
```

I realize now that it's not that easy. `snapshot_vfunc()` is protected,
like most virtual functions.

Closing this issue as the requested information has not been provided.  
Feel free to reopen if you can provide more information.
